snippet: Signs of a slowing economy and recent political upheavals in China add urgency to questions of how much control the state should exert, in business and in the lives of citizens.
abstract: News analysis; signs of a slowing economy combined with political upheavals in China have added urgency to questions of how much control the state should exert in both business and the lives of its citizens; although many economists have been urging the government to loosen controls over the financial system, such a change would involve a titanic power struggle.

byline.contributor: Jonathan Ansfield contributed reporting, and Li Bibo and Edy Yin contributed research.

lead_paragraph: Signs of a slowing economy and recent political upheavals in China add urgency to questions of how much control the state should exert, in business and in the lives of citizens.

headline.seo: China’s Unique Economic Model Gets New Scrutiny
headline.main: China’s Growth Slows, and Its Political Model Shows Limits
headline.print_headline: As Growth Slows, Doubts on China’s State-Driven Model
